channel.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
channel.description:
Hello moparscape community. I've been thinking of ways to make a drop down menu without using lists, main because I suck using lists like that. So I brought my jQuery knowledge together and made a jQuery Drop Down Menu. Live view @ [url=http://www.adonia.vacau.com/Robby/jQueryDDM.html]jQuery | Drop Down Menu[/url] The jQuery code I used, if you visited the live preview [code=javascript]$(document).ready (function(){ $("#jQDDM").click(function(){ //When click the DIV element #jQDDM it shows the DIV element .jQDDM $(".jQDDM").slideToggle("slow"); }); });[/code] The CSS code I used, if you visited the live preview [code=css]#jQDDM{border: 1px solid #4169e0; background-color: #c0c0c0; padding: 5px; width: 200px; margin: 0px auto; font-family: Trebuchet MS; color: #ffffff; font-size: 20px;} a:link{font-family: Trebuchet MS; color: #4169e0; font-size: 15px; text-decoration: none;} a:visited{color: #4169e0;} a:hover{text-decoration: underline;} .jQDDM{text-align: center; display: none;}[/code] The HTML code I used, if you visited the live preview [code=html]
Click to test!
This
is
a
jQuery
Drop
Down
Menu
[/code] Oh and don't forgot the library: Kind regards, Sibor aka Robby PS: Sorry for a poor explanation, it's late, I'm tired and I typed this thread up real quick

item.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

I would stick with jQuery drop downs for the next year or so.

Read full topic

item.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:8, topic:494764”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=612996.msg4239045#msg4239045 date=1361721312]

Not recommended. You can achieve a much better, faster and more semantic result using plain old CSS.

I don’t think a slide toggle is achievable in pure CSS right now.

Though I’m not a fan of how the HTML is structured for this.
[/quote]It is easily possible with CSS transitions.[/quote]

MDN Web Docs

Using CSS transitions

CSS transitions provide a way to control animation speed when changing CSS properties. Instead of having property changes take effect immediately, you can cause the changes in a property to take place over a period of time.

Read full topic

item.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“justaguy, post:4, topic:494764”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=612996.msg4238374#msg4238374 date=1361687866]
Not recommended. You can achieve a much better, faster and more semantic result using plain old CSS.
[/quote]

I don’t think a slide toggle is achievable in pure CSS right now.

Though I’m not a fan of how the HTML is structured for this.[/quote]It is easily possible with CSS transitions.

Read full topic

item.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

http://www.w3schools.com/cssref/sel_hover.asp

Excuse the w3schools but sometimes it’s alright just to reference. I’d use that over the jquery function, using a combination of CSS3 transitions and transforms you can practically achieve any effect you like

Read full topic

item.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
item.dc:creator: @Sibor Sibor
item.description:
@Sibor wrote:

Thanks guys on how I could improve this. I’m working on the .hover() rather than .click().

Also, the HTML is just so I could display it. @ RSCShadow

Read full topic

item.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

I used a similar method to store a form (instead of a separate page) on a site development I’m working on http://tinyurl.com/ajz597n
Click the second grey box link in the main content of the page.

I assume this was made for something similar, rather than being for primary navigation for example.


tags are hardly semantic in this instance, kill them, just use display block.

Read full topic

item.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

RSCShadow:

Not recommended. You can achieve a much better, faster and more semantic result using plain old CSS.

I don’t think a slide toggle is achievable in pure CSS right now.

Though I’m not a fan of how the HTML is structured for this.

Read full topic

item.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

RSCShadow:

Not recommended. You can achieve a much better, faster and more semantic result using plain old CSS.

This.

Also - don’t use line breaks as often as what you have been or better yet, don’t use them at all. Use the padding and margin CSS attributes

Read full topic

item.title: jQuery | Drop Down Menu
item.dc:creator: @Sibor Sibor
item.description:
@Sibor wrote:

Hello moparscape community.

I’ve been thinking of ways to make a drop down menu without using lists, main because I suck using lists like that. So I brought my jQuery knowledge together and made a jQuery Drop Down Menu.

Live view @ jQuery | Drop Down Menu

The jQuery code I used, if you visited the live preview

$(document).ready (function(){ $("#jQDDM").click(function(){ //When click the DIV element #jQDDM it shows the DIV element .jQDDM $(".jQDDM").slideToggle("slow"); }); });

The CSS code I used, if you visited the live preview

#jQDDM{border: 1px solid #4169e0; background-color: #c0c0c0; padding: 5px; width: 200px; margin: 0px auto; font-family: Trebuchet MS; color: #ffffff; font-size: 20px;} a:link{font-family: Trebuchet MS; color: #4169e0; font-size: 15px; text-decoration: none;} a:visited{color: #4169e0;} a:hover{text-decoration: underline;} .jQDDM{text-align: center; display: none;}

The HTML code I used, if you visited the live preview

[code=html]

Click to test!
This
is
a
jQuery
Drop
Down
Menu
[/code]

Oh and don’t forgot the library:

Kind regards,
Sibor aka Robby

PS: Sorry for a poor explanation, it’s late, I’m tired and I typed this thread up real quick

Read full topic
